channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Some Dual Nationals and Injured Palestinians Cross to Egypt
item.description: The Gaza border opened for the first such crossings since the war began, and state-owned TV showed families arriving in Egypt. Hundreds of people were expected to leave Gaza on Wednesday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Gaza walking through a gate to enter the Rafah border crossing to Egypt on Wednesday.

item.title: Frustrated Zelensky Says Ukraine’s War Effort Is Being Underestimated
item.description: As U.S. officials warned senators against halting military aid, President Volodymyr Zelensky said his troops’ achievements were “perceived as a given.”
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops during training in the Donetsk region on Saturday. Both sides have been burning through huge quantities of ammunition.

item.title: A World of Fear for Europe’s Jews
item.description: The Oct. 7 Hamas assault on Israel and a surge in acts of antisemitism have awakened a repressed horror in Jewish populations across the continent.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Observing a minute of silence during a rally in solidarity with Israel in Berlin on Oct. 22.

item.title: At UK Summit, Global Leaders Warn AI Could Cause ‘Catastrophic’ Harm
item.description: At a U.K. summit, 28 governments, including China and the U.S., signed a declaration agreeing to cooperate on evaluating the risks of artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Megan Specia
item.media:description: The mansion house at Bletchley Park, north of London. The country estate, home of Britain’s code-breaking efforts in World War II, is the site of a two-day summit focused on A.I. safety.

item.title: For China’s Jobless Young People, Hostels Are the Place to Be
item.description: Chinese backpacker hostels offering bunk beds for a few dollars a night have become hubs for the anxiety and ambitions of job-seeking youth.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Together Hostel in Shanghai in October. Youth hostels, costing a few dollars a night, have become concentrated hubs for young people in search of jobs in Chinese cities.

item.title: Israel Faces Hostage Dilemma in Gaza
item.description: The country has said there are two main goals in the war: Destroy Hamas and free the hostages held in Gaza. But are those goals compatible?
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of the hostages held in Gaza and their supporters during a demonstration on Sunday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Is a 2-State Solution Between Israel and Palestinians Still Feasible?
item.description: As President Biden and other Western leaders promote the idea, some diplomats and analysts say the Hamas-Israel war may breathe new life into it.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: From left, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, President Bill Clinton and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat at Camp David in 2000, when Israel and the Palestinians arguably came closest to striking a two-state settlement.

item.title: Iran Faces a Dilemma in the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: With Israel bent on crushing Iran’s ally Hamas, Tehran must decide whether it and the proxy militias it arms and trains will live up to its fiery rhetoric.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran last month denouncing Israel’s airstrikes in Gaza. Taking stronger action against Israel could bolster Iran’s revolutionary credentials but risk igniting a broader war.

item.title: How Germany’s Green Party Lost Its Luster
item.description: The party was riding high when it entered the government two years ago. Now it is stumbling, blamed for driving voters to the far right.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The prelude to an election event in Berlin in 2021, when the Green Party’s performance seemed to show a strong mandate to advance Germany’s transition toward a greener future.

item.title: Indian Opposition Figures Get Threat Notification From Apple
item.description: The notifications suggested that many opposition figures could be under “state-sponsored” surveillance, but even Apple said the warning could have been a false alarm.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Throngs of people fill an Apple store in Mumbai.

item.title: Maduro Tries to Squash Venezuela’s Election Campaign Before it Even Starts
item.description: The government’s move to annul the election of a candidate to challenge President Nicolás Maduro raises questions about its commitment to a free election.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, the leading opposition candidate, won a primary last month with 93 percent of the vote in a 10-candidate race.

item.title: Poland’s Ruling Party Casts Doubt on Election That Cost It Power
item.description: Loyalists of Poland’s Law and Justice party are questioning the legitimacy of the election won this month by an alliance of opposition parties.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, leader of the ruling conservative Law and Justice party, speaks to supporters in October.

item.title: New Zealand Volcano Owner Is Found Guilty of Safety Failure
item.description: The ruling brings an end to legal proceedings that began after the White Island eruption killed 22 people in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: White Island erupted on Dec. 9, 2019, with 47 people — including tour groups and their guides — on the island. Almost half of them were killed.

item.title: Bolivia Cuts Diplomatic Ties With Israel Over Strikes in Gaza
item.description: Chile and Colombia said they were recalling their ambassadors to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians inspecting damage to a house that airstrikes destroyed in Khan Younis, a southern Gaza city, on Wednesday.

item.title: Two More Arrests Made Over Destruction of Sycamore Gap Tree
item.description: More than a month after the tree was mysteriously cut down, the police in Britain said they had arrested two men in their 30s on suspicion of criminal damage.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Owen Humphreys/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers removed what remained of the Sycamore Gap tree along Hadrian’s Wall in Northumberland last month.

item.title: What to Know About the Gaza Departures
item.description: Thousands of foreign passport holders and people affiliated with international organizations are set to evacuate from Gaza to Egypt starting on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: Talking About Health Impacts of Climate Change Without Mentioning Fossil Fuels
item.description: A declaration on the public health impacts of climate change may lack two words: fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Public health experts sent an open letter to Sultan al-Jaber, the U.A.E. oil company boss presiding over the talks, urging commitment phase-out fossil fuels.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Lima
item.description: Lima is a city of contrasts and contradictions — gray and tropical, dense and isolated. Augusto Higa Oshiro, one of its writers, recommended books and authors that have captured its complexity.
item.dc:creator: Augusto Higa Oshiro and translated by Jennifer Shyue

item.title: Harris to Announce Steps to Curb Risks of A.I.
item.description: The vice president plans to flesh out a sweeping executive order President Biden signed this week and push toward global standards at a summit in London.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris will represent the United States at a summit on artificial intelligence organized by Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak.

item.title: Tropical Storm Pilar Kills at Least 1 in El Salvador
item.description: The storm was drifting north toward the Central American country early Wednesday. It was forecast to begin moving west, farther into the Pacific Ocean, later in the day.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Camilo Freedman/DPA Picture-Alliance, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Coast Guard members monitoring Tropical Storm Pilar on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Israel strikes a crowded area in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for casualties at the site of Israeli strikes in Jabalia refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip on Tuesday.

item.title: Egypt Says It Will Treat Injured Gazans in Its Hospitals
item.description: A gateway to the Gaza Strip has allowed some vital aid in but has yet to let anyone get out.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A truck driver waving Egyptian and Palestinian flags near the Rafah border crossing on Tuesday.

item.title: Video: Israeli Strike Hits Jabaliya Neighborhood in Gaza, Home to Refugee Camp
item.description: The Times analyzed satellite imagery and social media posts of the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Christoph Koettl and Bora Erden

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Aimed at Hamas Hits Jabaliya Refugee Camp in Gaza
item.description: Israel said it killed a Hamas leader at a refugee camp, but many other people were wounded and killed, Hamas said. The assault came as fuel, food and water shortages pushed civilians to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Karen Zraick and Emma Bubola
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The aftermath of the airstrike at the Jabaliya refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Israeli Troops Battle Into Gaza as Airstrike Draws Conflicting Claims
item.description: Photographs taken on Tuesday showed a large crater and significant damage to buildings at the Jabaliya neighborhood in northern Gaza, the site of a densely populated refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli troops on the border with the Gaza Strip, the territory where Israel’s ground forces are battling Hamas, on Tuesday.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthi Militia Says It Launched Missiles and Drones Toward Israel
item.description: The Israeli military said it had thwarted a batch of “aerial threats” but did not say who was behind them.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Saeed Al-Batati
item.media:description: A military parade in Sana, Yemen, last month.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Increases Risks of Attacks on Americans, F.B.I. Warns
item.description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, said the war is raising the risk of foreign terrorist attacks against Americans as well as domestic violent extremist attacks targeting Jewish and Muslim communities.
item.dc:creator: FedNet
item.media:description: Christopher Wray, director of the F.B.I., testifying in front of the Senate Homeland Security and Government Affairs committee on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Strikes Densely Populated Area
item.description: Plus the power of music at a volatile time.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for casualties in the Jabaliya neighborhood in Gaza yesterday.

item.title: Johnson’s Israel Aid Bill Sets Stage for a Clash Over Security Assistance
item.description: By splitting money for Israel’s war effort from aid to Ukraine and coupling it with spending cuts, Speaker Mike Johnson has put the House on a collision course with the Senate and President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson appears to have structured the Israel legislation in an effort to keep his conference united in the early days of his speakership.

item.title: Jacob Lew Is Confirmed as U.S. Ambassador to Israel
item.description: The vote reflected deep partisan divisions over Jacob Lew’s nomination, which nearly all Senate Republicans voted against.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew, a former Treasury secretary, was confirmed at a time when Congress was rushing to respond to Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel.

item.title: Mexico’s Scary Dancing Nun, “La Monja de la Feria,” Is a Video Sensation
item.description: “La Monja de la Feria,” a scary nun character, has delighted and unsettled millions with popular videos that showcase her dance moves atop a fair ride. But why is this peculiar scene so popular?
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: “La monja de la Feria” performing in Durango, Mexico.

item.title: American Commandos Are in Israel Helping to Locate Hostages, Pentagon Says
item.description: A Defense Department official, Christopher P. Maier, declined to say how many U.S. Special Operations forces were currently in Israel. But other U.S. officials say the Defense Department has dispatched several dozen commandos in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration outside the United Nations last week symbolizing the kidnapped hostages in Israel.

item.title: Photos show an explosion has caused heavy damage in Gaza’s Jabaliya neighborhood.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for casualties after an Israeli airstrike on Tuesday in Jabaliya refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Raises the Potential for an Attack Against the U.S., FBI Says
item.description: Since the attacks by Hamas, antisemitic threats in the U.S. have reached “historic levels,” the agency’s director said. Threats against Muslims have also increased.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher Wray, right, director of the F.B.I., testifying in front of the Senate Homeland Security and Government Affairs committee on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel’s U.N. Ambassador Criticized for Wearing a Yellow Star of David
item.description: Dani Dayan, chairman of Yad Vashem museum in Jerusalem, said Israelis should instead display the country’s flag as a sign of strength.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Israel’s U.N. ambassador, Gilad Erdan, at the U.N. headquarters in New York City on Monday.

item.title: Russia Detains Two Soldiers Suspected of Killing 9 Civilians
item.description: The arrest in an occupied area of Ukraine was a rare admission by Moscow that its forces may have committed a crime against Ukrainian civilians. Experts warned that it might just be political posturing.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Russian soldier on duty in Volnovakha, Ukraine, last year. Russian forces took control of the city shortly after the invasion began in 2022.

item.title: A Footpath in England, Torn Down, Keeps Being Rebuilt by ‘Fairies’
item.description: A small bridge in the English village of Stiffkey, northeast of Cambridge, was dismantled last year. It was rebuilt overnight, dismantled a second time and rebuilt again.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: This makeshift footbridge was the second to appear within a month at Stiffkey, one of the biggest areas of salt marsh in Europe.

item.title: Daniel Barenboim’s Academy of Music and Middle-East Peace
item.description: Students from the Middle East come to Berlin to study music with the star conductor Daniel Barenboim. Now the Israel-Hamas war is testing their ideals.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times

item.title: Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind Farm Gets Federal Approval
item.description: The decision comes as other projects to build wind farms along the Atlantic Coast have run into trouble.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Bob O'Connor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tower sections of wind turbines at New Bedford Marine Commerce Terminal in Massachusetts.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Is Sole Bidder for 2034 World Cup
item.description: Australia announced it would not bid, clearing the way for the Saudis to bring soccer’s biggest tournament back to the Gulf.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Argentina won the World Cup in Qatar last year. The 2034 tournament is expected to return to the Gulf.

item.title: In Cyberattacks, Iran Shows Signs of Improved Hacking Capabilities
item.description: A monthslong hacking campaign targeted the governments of regional rivals, including Israel, and marked a turn, a new report says, as the attacks were used to collect intelligence, not just disrupt services.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Krolik and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burning an Israeli flag in Tehran this month. In its shadow war with Israel, Iran has stepped up its hacking capabilities, a new report says.

item.title: U.S. Looks to Allay European Fears of a Subsidy War
item.description: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, argued in a speech in Germany that the Biden administration’s climate law is not protectionist.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, said the United States was continuing to look for ways to improve coordination with Europe on climate and energy security initiatives.

item.title: Hezbollah Hesitates as Israel Strikes Gaza
item.description: After years of spoiling for a fight with Israel, the group is torn between maintaining its credibility as a defender of the Palestinians, and its hesitation to drag Lebanon into a full-scale war.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Hezbollah, a Lebanese militant group backed by Iran, has long positioned itself as a defender of the Palestinians. But can it maintain its reputation and still sit out a war with Israel?

item.title: Suspected Gunman Holds a Hostage in Post Office Near Tokyo
item.description: The suspect, said by the Japanese media to be 86, was held after the police stormed a post office once two employees had reached safety.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Police officers taking position outside the post office where a man believed to have a gun was holed up in Warabi, just outside Tokyo, on Tuesday.

item.title: King Charles, Visiting Kenya, Faces Calls to Answer for Colonial Abuses
item.description: Older Kenyans who lived through the British colonial period want an apology and reparations. Younger Kenyans want an acknowledgment of more recent alleged abuses by British companies and troops.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Patrick Meinhardt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph Macharia Mwangi is among the last surviving veterans of the Mau Mau rebellion against British colonial forces in Kenya in the 1950s. He has a message for King Charles.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Israel advances on Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery position near the border with Gaza yesterday.

item.title: Hochul Visits Cornell to Reassure Jewish Students Rattled by Online Threats
item.description: “I want them to know they are not alone,” New York’s governor said of the students, after posts on a student forum called for violence against Jews.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Maag
item.media:description: The state police on guard at the Center for Jewish Living at Cornell University on Monday after online threats.

item.title: Famed Iranian Rights Lawyer Reportedly Jailed and Beaten
item.description: Nasrin Sotoudeh was one of several activists arrested at the funeral of Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old girl who died after not wearing a head covering in public, in a case that drew parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Nasrin Sotoudeh, a lawyer and human rights activist, at her house in Tehran, Iran, in 2013.

item.title: Ori Megidish, an Israeli Soldier, Is Rescued After Hamas Abduction
item.description: The 19-year-old soldier was taken after Hamas gunmen overran and briefly captured a military base in Nahal Oz, just east of the northern Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Johnatan Reiss and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Private Ori Megidish, center, celebrating on Monday after being rescued from captivity in Gaza.

item.title: ‘Friends’ Cast Release Statement on Matthew Perry’s Death
item.description: Perry’s co-stars on the long-running NBC sitcom released a joint statement after the actor’s death over the weekend at 54.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Television, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Matthew Perry, third from right, with his “Friends” castmates: From left, David Schwimmer, Courteney Cox, Jennifer Aniston, Matt LeBlanc and Lisa Kudrow.

item.title: Bloomberg and 34,000 Donors Combine to Give $88 Million to Israel Medical Service
item.description: The former New York City mayor and billionaire philanthropist said he would match $44 million in donations from nearly 34,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Michael Bloomberg at a 2016 gala for the American Friends of Magen David Adom.

item.title: Settler Violence Rising Against Palestinians in the West Bank
item.description: More than 100 Palestinians have been killed, more than 2,000 injured and nearly 1,000 forcibly displaced by Israeli settlers since Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Rami Nazzal
item.media:description: Damaged properties last week at the West Bank village of Wadi al-Siq. Representatives of a community of 200 Bedouin herders living there said that Jewish settlers, accompanied by police officers and Israeli soldiers, had attacked the village on Oct. 12.

item.title: Gazans, as Bombs Fall, Say Escape Is Impossible
item.description: As bombs fell in the background, Palestinians in the Hamas-ruled territory recounted a struggle to survive.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Abu Bakr Bashir and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: Palestinians walking among the rubble in the Tel al-Hawa neighborhood of Gaza City on Monday.

item.title: Democratic Rifts Over Israel Burst to the Forefront in Congress
item.description: The divisions are erupting as the House weighs a G.O.P. bid to censure the only Palestinian-American member of Congress for criticizing Israel and votes on a large aid bill to back Israel in the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats are openly at odds as Congress is set to tackle sweeping emergency spending legislation to address the ongoing conflict in Gaza.

item.title: Netanyahu Rejects Calls for a Cease-fire Against Hamas in Gaza
item.description: Israel’s prime minister adopted a defiant tone in a rare news briefing, saying that the country would not agree to a halt in attacks because, he argued, doing so would strengthen Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abir Sultan/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Forces Advance on Gaza City
item.description: Plus we remember Matthew Perry.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank, seen from Sderot, operating in Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Biden’s Support for Israel Now Comes With Words of Caution
item.description: The administration has become more critical of Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks, a shift that U.S. officials attribute to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The change in President Biden’s tone has occurred against the backdrop of global denunciations of Israel’s actions and an explosion of divisive protests in the United States.

item.title: Israelis Advance on Gaza City, as Netanyahu Rules Out Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel’s leaders vowed to destroy Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, after the deadly Oct. 7 attack, and Israeli ground forces are closing in on the city from three directions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Lauren Leatherby, Vivian Yee and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli artillery position near the border with Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Israel Shrouds Gaza Invasion in Secrecy
item.description: After an air campaign that killed thousands of Palestinians, Israel has begun a ground assault, but it took hours for outside observers to understand what was happening. The ambiguity was intentional.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank, seen from Israel, operating in Gaza on Monday.
